DataElement.preferredName: Recurrent Ipsilateral Breast Tumor Histology Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the category of tumor related to the classification based on histology (the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues) of recurrent ipsilateral (the same side of body) breast cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Recurrent Ipsilateral Breast Tumor Histology Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to classification based on histology (the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues) of recurrent ipsilateral (the same side of body) breast cancer.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: occurring again.:Having to do with the same side of the body.:One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: Having to do with the same side of the body.
One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.origin: ECOG CRF:Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredName: Recurrent Ipsilateral Breast Tumor Histology Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the category of tumor histology in ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that is not confined to the epithelium, and has spread to the surrounding stroma.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that is not confined to the epithelium, and has spread to the surrounding stroma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Both invasive carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Both invasive carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ

A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.
